I wil make bold with your obstreperous aide,
(Conceiue me) for your fee, sir. In meane time,
You, that haue so much law, I know ha' the conscience,
Not to be couetous of what is mine.
Good sir, I thanke you for my plate: 'twill helpe
To set vp a yong man. Good faith, you looke
As you were cos●iue; best go home, and purge, sir.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Bid him, eat lettuce well: my wittie mischiefe,
Let me embrace thee. O, that I could now
Transforme thee to a VENVS— MOSCA, goe,
Streight, take my habit of Clarissimo;
And walke the streets; be seene, torment 'hem more:
We must pursew, as well as plot. Who would
Haue lost this feast?

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: I doubt it will loose them.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: O, my recouery shall recouer all.
That I could now but thinke on some disguise,
To meet 'hem in: and aske 'hem questions.
How I would vexe 'hem still, at euery turne?

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Sir, I can fit you.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Canst thou?

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Yes, I know
One o' the Commandatori, sir, so like you,
Him will I streight make drunke, and bring you his habit.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: A rare disguise, and answering thy braine!
O, I will be a sharpe disease vnto 'hem.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Sir, you must looke for curses—

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Till they burst;
The Foxe fares euer best, when he is curst.
AM I enough disguis'd?

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: All my ambition is to fright him, onely.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: If you could ship him away, 'twere excellent.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: To Zant, or to Alepo?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Yes, and ha' his
Aduentures put i' th' booke of voyages,
And his guld story registred, for truth?
Well, gentlemen, when I am in, a while,
And that you thinke vs warme in our discourse,
Know your approaches.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: Trust it to our care.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Saue you, faire lady. Is sir POLL. within?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: I do not know, sir.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: 'Pray you, say vnto him,
Here is a merchant, vpon earnest businesse,
Desires to speake with him.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: I will see, sir.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: 'Pray you.
I see, the family is all female, here.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: He sai's, sir, he has waighty affaires of state,
That now require him whole, some other time
You may possesse him.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: 'Pray you say againe,
If those require him whole, these will exact him▪
VVhereof I bring him tidings. VVhat might be
His graue affaire of state, now? how, to make
Bolognian sauseges, here, in Venice, sparing
One o'th'ingredients.

sp.speaker: VVOM.
sp.l: Sir, he sai's, he knowes
By your word, tidings, that you are no states-man,
And therefore, wills you stay.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Sweet, 'pray you returne him,
I haue not read so many proclamations,
And studied them, for words, as he has done,
But— Here he deignes to come.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Sir, I must craue
Your courteous pardon. There hath chanc'd (to day)
Vnkinde disaster, 'twixt my lady, and mee:
And I was penning my apologie
To giue her satifaction, as you came, now.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Sir, I am grieu'd, I bring you worse disaster;
The gentleman, you met at th' port, to day,
That told you, he was newly arriu'd—

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: I, was
A fugitiue punke?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: No, sir, a spie, set on you:
And, he has made relation to the Senate,
That you profest to him, to haue a plot,
To sell the state of Venice, to the Turke.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: O me!

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: For which, warrants are sign'd by this time▪
To apprehend you, and to search your study,
For papers—

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Alasse, sir. I haue none, but notes,
Drawne out of play-bookes—

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: All the better, sir.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: And some essayes. What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Sir, best
Conuay your selfe into a sugar-chest,
Or, if you could lie round, a fraile were rare:
And I could send you, aboard.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Sir, I but talk'd so,
For discourse sake, They knocke without. merely.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Harke, they are there.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: I am a wretch, a wretch.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: What, will you doe, sir?
Ha you ne're a curren-but to leape into?
They'll put you to the racke, you must be sudden.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Sir, I haue an ingine—

sp.speaker: (MER. 3.
sp.l: Sir POLITIQVE WOVLD-BE?

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Where is he?)

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: That I haue thought vpon, before time.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: (I shall ne're indure the torture.)
Mary, it is, sir, of a tortoyse-shell,
Fitted, for these extremities: 'pray you sir, helpe me.
Here, I' haue a place, sir, to put backe my leggs,
(Please you to lay it on, sir) with this cap,
And my blacke gloues, I'le lye, sir, like a tortoyse,
Till they are gone.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: And, call you this an ingine?

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Mine owne deuice— good sir, bid my wiues women
They rush in. To burne my papers.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: Where's he hid?

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: We must,
And will, sure, find him.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Which is his study?

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: What
Are you, sir?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: I'am a merchant, that came heere
To looke vpon this tortoyse.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: S^t. MARKE!
What beast is this?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: It is a fish.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Come out, here.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Nay, you may strike him, sir, and tread vpon him:
Hee'll beare a cart.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: What, to runne ouer him?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: Let's iump, vpon him.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Can he not go?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: He creeps, sir.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: Let's see him creepe.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: No, good sir, you will hurt him.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: (Heart) I'le see him creepe; or pricke his guts.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: Come out, here.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: 'Pray you sir, (creepe a little)

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: Foorth.

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Yet furder.

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Good sir, (creep)

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: We'll see his legs.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: They pu● of the shel and disco|uer him. Gods so, he has garters!

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: I, and gloues!

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: Is this
Your fearefull tortoyse?

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Now, sir POLL. we are euen;
For your next proiect, I shall be prepar'd:
I am sorry, for the funerall of your notes, sir.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: 'Twere a rare motion, to be seene in Fleet-street!

sp.speaker: MER. 2.
sp.l: I, i'the terme.

sp.speaker: MER. 1.
sp.l: Or Smithfield, in the faire.

sp.speaker: MER. 3.
sp.l: Me thinkes, tis but a melancholique sight!

sp.speaker: PER.
sp.l: Farewell, most politique tortoyse.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Where's my lady?
Knowes shee of this?

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: Enquire.
O, I shall be the fable of all feasts;
The freight of the gazetti; ship-boyes tale;
And, which is worst, euen talke for ordinaries.

sp.speaker: WOM.
sp.l: My lady's come most melancholique, home,
And say's, sir, she will straight to sea, for physick.

sp.speaker: POL.
sp.l: And I, to shunne, this place, and clime for euer;
Creeping, with house, on backe: and thinke it well,
To shrinke my poore head, in my politique shell.

div.head: Act IIII. Scene V.
div.stage: The first, in the habit of a Com|mandadora: the other, of a Clarissimo. VOLPONE, MOSCA.

sp.l: AM I then like him?

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: O, sir, you are he:
No man can seuer you.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: But, what am I?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: 'Fore heau'n, a braue Clarissimo, thou becom'st it!
Pitty, thou wert not borne one.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: If I hold
My made one, 'twill be well.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I'le goe, and see
What newes, first, at the court.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Doe so. My FOXE
Is out on his hole, and, ere he shall re-enter,
I'le make him languish, in his borrow'd case,
Except he come to composition, with me:
ANDROGINO, CASTRONE, NANO.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Goe, recreate your selues, abroad; goe, sport:
So, now I haue the keies, and am possest.
Since he will, needes, be dead, afore his time,
I'le burie him, or gaine by him. I'am his heire:
And so will keepe me, till he share at least.
To cosen him of all, were but a cheat
Well plac'd; no man would construe it a sinne:
Let his sport pay for't, this is call'd the FOXE-trap.
THey say, the court is set.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: We must maintaine
Our first tale good, for both our reputations.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Why? mine's no tale: my sonne would, there, haue kild me.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: That's true, I had forgot: mine is, I am sure.
But, for your will, sir.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: I, I'le come vpon him,
For that, hereafter, now his Patron's dead.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Signior CORVINO! and CORBACCIO! sir,
Much ioy vnto you.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: The sodaine good,
Dropt downe vpon you—

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: (And, none knowes (how)
From old VOLPONE, sir.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Out, errant knaue.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Let not your too much wealth, sir, make your furious.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Away, thou varlet.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Why sir?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Do'st thou mocke me?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: You mocke the world, sir, did you not change wills?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Out, harlot.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: O! belike you are the man,
Signior CORVINO? 'faith, you carry it well;
You grow not mad withall: I loue your spirit.
You are not ouer-leauen'd, with your fortune.
You should ha' some would swell, now like a wine-fat,
With such an Autumne— Did he gi'you all, sir?

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Auoid, you rascall.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Troth, your wife has shew'ne
Her selfe a very woman: but, you are well,
You neede not care, you haue a good estate,
To beare it out, sir, better by this chance.
Except CORBACCIO haue a share?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Hence, varlet.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: You will not be a' knowne, sir: why 'tis wise.
Thus doe all gam'sters, at all games, dissemble.
No man will seeme to winne. Here, comes my vulture,
Heauing his beake vp i' the ayre, and snuffing.
OVt-stript thus, by a parasite? a slaue?
Would run on errands? and make legs, for crummes?
Well, what I'le do—

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: The court staies for you worship.
I eêne reioyce, sir, at your worships happinesse,
And that it fell into so learned hands,
That vnderstand the fingering.—

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I meane to be a sutor to your worship,
For the small tenement, out of reparations;
That, at the end of your long row of houses,
By the piscaria: it was, in VOLPONE'S time,
Your predecessor, ere he grew diseas'd,
A handsome, pretty, custom'd, bawdy-house,
As any was in Venice (none disprais'd)
But fell with him; his body, and that house
Decay'd, together.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Come, sir, leaue your prating.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Why, if your worship giue me but your hand,
That I may ha' the refusall; I haue done.
'Tis a meere toy, to you, sir; candle rents:
As your learn'd worship knowes—

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: What doe I know?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Mary no end of your wealth, sir, god decrease it.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Mistaking knaue! what, mock'st thou my mis-fortune?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: His blessing on your heart, sir, would 'twere more.
(Now, to my first, againe; at the next corner.)
SEe, in our habite! see the impudent varlet!

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: That I could shoote mine eies at him, like gun-stones.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: But, is this true, sir, of the parasite?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Againe, t'afflict vs? monster?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: In good faith, sir,
I'am hartily greeu'd, a beard of your graue length
Should be so ouer-reach'd. I neuer brook'd
That parasites haire, me thought his nose should cosen:
There still was somewhat, in his looke, did promise
The bane of a Clarissimo.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Knaue—

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Me thinkes,
Yet you, that are so traded i' the world,
A witty merchant, the fine bird, CORVINO,
That haue such morall emblemes on your name,
Should not haue sung you shame; and dropt your cheese:
To let the FOXE laugh at your emptinesse.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Sirrah, you thinke, the priuiledge of the place,
And your red saucy cap, that seemes (to me)
Nayl'd to your iolt-head, with those two cecchines,
Can warrant your abuses; come you, hither:
You shall perceiue, sir, I dare beate you. Approch.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: No haste, sir, I doe know your valure, well:
Since you durst publish what you are, sir.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Tarry,
I'ld speake, with you.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Sir, sir, another time —

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Nay, now.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: O god, sir! I were a wise man,
Would stand the fury of a distracted cuckold.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: What! Mosca walkes by 'hem. come againe?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Vpon 'hem, MOSCA; saue me,

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: The ayre's infected, where he breathes.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Lets flye him.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Excellent Basiliske! turne vpon the vulture.
VVEll, flesh-flie, it is sommer with you, now;
Your winter will come on.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Good Aduocate,
'Pray thee, not raile, nor threaten out of place, thus;
Thou'lt make a soloecisme (as madame sayes.)
Get you a biggen, more: your braine breakes loose.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Would you ha' me beate the insolent slaue?
Throw dirt, vpon his first good cloathes?

sp.speaker: VOLT,
sp.l: This same
Is, doubtlesse, some familiar!

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Sir, the court
In troth, stayes for you. I am mad, a mule,
That neuer read IVSTINIAN, should get vp,
And ride an Aduocate. Had you no quirke,
To auoide gullage, sir, by such a creature?
I hope you doe but iest; he has not done't:
This's but confederacy, to blind the rest.
You are the heire?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: A strange, officious,
Trouble-some knaue! thou dost torment me.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I know—
It cannot be, sir, that you should be cosen'd;
'Tis not within the wit of man, to doe it:
You are so wise, so prudent, and, 'tis fit,
That wealth, and wisdome still, should goe together.

div.head: Act V. Scene 10.
div.stage: AVOCATORIA, 4. NOTARIO, COMMANDADORE, BONARIO, CELIA, CORBACCIO, COR|VINO, VOLTORE, VOLPONE.

sp.l: ARe all the parties, here?

sp.speaker: NOT.
sp.l: All, but the Aduocate.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: And, here he comes.

sp.speaker: AVO.
sp.l: Then bring 'hem foorth to sentence.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: O, my most honour'd fathers, let your mercy
Once winne vpon your iustice, to forgiue—
I am distracted—

sp.speaker: (VOLP.
sp.l: What will he doe, now?)

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: O,
I know not which t'addresse my selfe to, first,
Whether your father-hoods, or these innocents—

sp.speaker: (CORV.
sp.l: Will he betray himselfe?)

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Whom, equally,
I haue abus'd, out of most couetous endes—

sp.speaker: (CORV.
sp.l: The man is mad?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: What's that!

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: He is possest.)

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: For which; now strooke in conscience, here I prostrate
My selfe, at your offended feet, for pardon.

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.2.
sp.l: Arise.

sp.speaker: CEL.
sp.l: O heau'n, how iust thou art!

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I'am caught
I'mine owne noose—

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Be constant, sir, nought now
Can helpe, but impudence.

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Speake forward.

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: It is not passion in me, reuerend fathers,
But onely conscience, conscience my good sires,
That makes me, now, tell truth. That parasite,
That knaue hath been the instrument of all.

sp.speaker: AVO.
sp.l: Where is that knaue? fetch him.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I goe.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Graue fathers,
This man's distracted; he confest it, now:
For, hoping to be old VOLPONE'S heire,
Who now is dead —

sp.speaker: AVOC. 3.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: Is VOLPONE dead?

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Dead since, graue fathers—

sp.speaker: BON.
sp.l: O, sure vengeance!

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Stay,
Then, he was no deceiuer?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: O, no, none:
The parasite, graue fathers.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: He do's speake,
Out of meere enuie, 'cause the seruant's made
The thing, he gap't for; please your father-hoods,
This is the truth: though, I'le not iustifie
The other, but he may be some-deale faulty.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: I, to your hopes, as well as mine, CORVINO:
But I'le vse modesty. Pleaseth your wisdomes
To viewe these certaine notes, and but conferre them;
As I hope fauour, they shall speake clear truth.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: The deuill ha's entred him!

sp.speaker: BON.
sp.l: Or bides in you.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: We haue done ill, by a publike officer,
To send for him, if he be heire.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: For whom?

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Him, that they call the parasite.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: 'Tis true;
He is a man, of great estate, now left.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Goe you, and learne his name; and say, the court
Intreates his presence, here; but, to the clearing
Of some few doubts.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: This same's a labyrinth!

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Stand you vnto your first report?

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: My state,
My life, my fame—

sp.speaker: BON.
sp.l: (Where is't?)

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Are at the stake.

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Is yours so too?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: The Aduocate's a knaue:
And has a forked tongue—

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: (Speake to the point.)

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: So is the parasite, too.

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: This is confusion.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: I doe beseech your father-hoods, read but those;

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: And credit nothing, the false spirit hath writ:
It cannot be, but he is possest, graue fathers.
TO make a snare, for mine owne necke! and run
My head into it, wilfully! with laughter!
When I had newly scap't, was free, and cleare!
Out of mere wantonnesse! Ô, the dull deuill
Was in this braine of mine, when I deuis'd it;
And MOSCA gaue it second: he must now
Helpe to ●eare vp this veyne, or we bleed dead.
How now! who let you loose? whither goe you, now?
What? to buy ginger-bread? or to drowne kitlings?

sp.speaker: NAN.
sp.l: Sir, master MOSCA call'd vs out of doores,
And bid vs all goe play, and tooke the keies.

sp.speaker: AND.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Did master MOSCA take the keyes? why, so!
I am farder, in. These are my fine conceipts!
I must be merry, with a mischiefe to me!
What a vile wretch was I, that could not beare
My fortune soberly? I must ha' my crotchets?
And my conundrums! well, goe you, and seeke him:
His meaning may be truer, then my feare.
Bid him, he streight come to me, to the court;
Thither will I, and, if 't be possible,
Vn-screw my aduocate, vpon new hopes:
When I prouok'd him, then I lost my selfe.
THese things can nere be reconcil'd. He, here,
Professeth, that the gentleman was wrong'd;
And that the gentlewoman was brought thither,
Forc'd by her husband: and there left.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Most true.

sp.speaker: CEL.
sp.l: How ready is heau'n to those, that pray!

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: But, that
VOLPONE would haue rauish'd her, he holds
Vtterly false; knowing his impotence.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Graue fathers, he is possest; againe, I say,
Possest: nay, if there be possession,
And obsession, he has both.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: Here comes our officer.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: The parasite will streight be, here, graue fathers.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: You might inuent some other name, sir varlet.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: Did not the notarie meet him?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Not that I know.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: His comming will cleare all.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: Yet it is mistie.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Volpone whis|pers the Aduo|cate. May't please your father hoods—

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Sir, the parasite
Will'd me to tell you, that his master liues;
That you are still the man; your hopes the same;
And this was, onely a iest—

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Sir, to trie
If you were, firme, and how you stood affected.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Art' sure he liues?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Doe I liue, sir?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: O me!
I was to violent.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Sir, you may redeeme it,
They said, you were possest; fall downe, and seeme so:
Voltore falls. I'le helpe to make it good. God blesse the man!
(Stop your wind hard, and swell) see, see, see, see!
He vomits crooked pinnes! his eyes are set,
Like a dead hares, hung in a poulters shop!
His mouth's running away! doe you see, signior?
Now, 'tis in his belly.

sp.speaker: (CORV.
sp.l: I, the deuill!)

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Now, in his throate.

sp.speaker: (CORV.
sp.l: I, I perceiue it plaine.)

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: 'Twill out, t'will out; stand cleere. See, where it flies!
In shape of a blew toad, with a battes wings!
Doe not you see it, sir?

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: What? I thinke I doe.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: 'Tis too manifest.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Looke! he comes t'himselfe!

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Take good heart, the worst is past, sir.
You are dis-possest.

sp.speaker: ATO. 1
sp.l: What accident is this?

sp.speaker: AVO.
sp.l: Sodaine, and full of wonder!

sp.speaker: ATO. 3.
sp.l: If he were.
Possest, as it appeares, all this is nothing.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: He has beene, often, subbiect to these fits,

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Shew him that writing, do you know it, sir?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Deny it, sir, forsweare it, know it not.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Yes, I doe know it well, it is my hand:
But all, that it containes, is false.

sp.speaker: BON. 3.
sp.l: O practise!

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: What maze is this!

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Is he not guilty, then,
Whom you, there, name the parasite?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Graue fathers,
No more then, his good patron, old VOLPONE.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Why, he is dead?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: O no, my honor'd fathers.
He liues—

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: How! liues?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Liues.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: This is subtler, yet!

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: You said, he was dead?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: Neuer.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: You said so?

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: I heard so.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Here comes the gentleman make him way.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: A stoole.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 4.
sp.l: A proper man! and were VOLPONE dead,
A fit match for my daughter.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 3.
sp.l: Giue him way.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: MOSCA, I was a'most lost, the Aduocate
Had betray'd all; but, now, it is recouer'd:
Al's o' the hinge againe—say, I am liuing.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: What busie knaue is this! most reuerend fathers,
I sooner, had attended your graue pleasures,
But that my order, for the funerall
Of my deare patron did require me—

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: (MOSCA!)

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Whom I intend to bury, like a gentleman.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I, quicke, and cosen me of all.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: Still stranger!
More intricate!

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: And come about againe!

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: It is a match, my daughter is bestow'd.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: (Wil you gi'me halfe?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: First, I'le be hang'd.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: I know,
Your voice is good, cry not so lowd')

sp.speaker: AVO. 1.
sp.l: Demand
The Aduocate. Sir, did not you affirme,
VOLPONE was aliue?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Yes, and he is;
This gent'man told me so, (thou shalt haue halfe.)

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Whose drunkard is this same? speake some, that know him:
I neuer saw his face. (I cannot now
Affoord it you so cheape.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: No?)

sp.speaker: AVO 1.
sp.l: What say you?

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: The officer told mee.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I did, graue fathers,
And will maintaine, he liues, with mine owne life.
And, that this creature told me. (I was borne,
With all good starres my enemies.)

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Most graue fathers,
If such an insolence, as this, must passe
Vpon me, I am silent: 'twas not this,
For which you sent, I hope.

sp.speaker: AVO. 2.
sp.l: Take him away.

sp.speaker: (VOLP.
sp.l: MOSCA.)

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: Let him be whipt.

sp.speaker: (VOLP.
sp.l: Wilt thou betray me?
Cosen me?)

sp.speaker: AOC. 3.
sp.l: And taught to beare himselfe
Toward a person of his ranke.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: I humbly thank your father-hoods.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Soft, soft: whipt?
And loose all that I haue? if I confesse,
It cannot be much more.

sp.speaker: AVO. 4.
sp.l: Sir, are you married?

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: They'll be ally'd, He puts off his disguise. anon; I must be resolute:
The FOXE shall, here, vncase.

sp.speaker: (MOS.
sp.l: Patron.)

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: Nay, now,
My ruines shall not come alone; your match
I'le hinder sure: my substance shall not glew you,
Nor screw you, into a family.

sp.speaker: (MOS.
sp.l: Why, patron!)

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: I am VOLPONE, and this is my knaue;
This, his owne knaue; this, auarices foole;
This, a Chimaera of wittall, foole, and knaue;
And, reuerend fathers, since we all can hope
Nought, but a sentence, let's not now despaire it.
You heare me briefe.

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: May it please your father-hoods—

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: silence.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: The knot is now vndone, by miracle!

sp.speaker: AVOC. 2.
sp.l: Nothing can be more cleare.

sp.speaker: AVO. 3.
sp.l: Or can more proue
These innocent.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: Giue 'hem their liberty.

sp.speaker: BON.
sp.l: Heauen could not, long, let such grosse crimes be hid.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 2.
sp.l: If this be held the high way to get riches,
May I be poore.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 3.
sp.l: This 's not the gaine, but torment.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: These possesse wealth, as sicke men possesse feuers,
Which, trulyer may be said to possesse them.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 2.
sp.l: Disroabe that parasite.

sp.speaker: CORV. MOS.
sp.l: Most honor'd fathers.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: Can you plead ought to stay the course of iustice?
If you can, speake.

sp.speaker: CORV. VOLT.
sp.l: We beg fauor,

sp.speaker: CEL.
sp.l: And mercy.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: You hurt your innocence, suing for the guilty.
Stand forth; and, first, the parasite. You appeare
T' haue beene the chiefest minister, if not plotter,
In all these lewd impostures; and now, lastly,
Haue, with your impudence, abus'd the court,
And habit of a gentleman of Venice,
Being a fellow of no birth, or bloud:
For which, our sentence is, first thou be whipt;
Then liue perpetuall prisoner in our gallies.

sp.speaker: VOLT.
sp.l: I thanke you, for him.

sp.speaker: MOS.
sp.l: Ban● to thy wooluish nature.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: Deliuer him to the Saffi. Thou, VOLPONE,
By bloud, and ranke a gentleman, canst not fall
Vnder like censure; but our iudgement on thee
Is, that thy substance all be straight confiscate
To the hospitall, of the Incurabili:
And, since the most was gotten by imposture,
By faining lame, gout, palsey, and such diseases,
Thou art to lie in prison, crampt with irons,
Till thou bee'st sicke, and lame indeed. Remoue him.

sp.speaker: VOLP.
sp.l: This is call'd mortifying of a FOXE.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: Thou VOLTORE, to take away the scandale
Thou hast giu'n all worthy men, of thy profession,
Art banish'd from their fellowship, and our state.
CORBACCIO, bring him neere. We here possesse
Thy sonne, of all thy state; and confine thee
To the monasterie of San' Spirito:
Where, since thou knew'st not how to liue well here,
Thou shalt be learn'd to die well.

sp.speaker: CORB.
sp.l: Ha! what said he?

sp.speaker: COM.
sp.l: You shall know anone, sir.

sp.speaker: AVOC.
sp.l: Thou CORVINO, shalt
Be straight imbarqu'd from thine owne house, and row'd
Round about Venice, through the grand canale,
Wearing a cap, with faire, long asses eares,
In stead of hornes: and, so to mount (a paper
Pin'd on thy brest) to the berlino —

sp.speaker: CORV.
sp.l: Yes,
And, haue mine eies beat out with stinking fish,
Bruis'd fruit, and rotten egges—'Tis well. I'am glad,
I shall not see my shame, yet.

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: And to expiate
Thy wrongs done to thy wife, thou art to send her
Home, to her father, with her dowrie trebled:
And these are all your iudgements.

sp.speaker: (ALL.
sp.l: Honour'd fathers.)

sp.speaker: AVOC. 1.
sp.l: Which may not be reuok'd. Now, you begin,
When crimes are done, and past, and to be punish'd,
To thinke what your crimes are: away with them.
Let all, that see these vices thus rewarded,
Take heart, and loue to study'hem. Mischiefes feed
Like beasts, till they be fat, and then they bleed.
THe seasoning of a play is the applause.
Now, though the FOXE be punish'd by the lawes,
He, yet, doth hope there is no suffring due,
For any fact, which he hath done 'gainst you;
If there be, sensure him: here he, doubtfull, stands.
If not, fare iouially, and clap your hands.

div.p: This Comoedie vvas first acted, in the yeere 1605.

The principall Comoedians were,
RIC. BVRBADGE.
HEN. CONDEL.
WILL. SLY.
IOH. HEMINGS.
IOH. LOWIN.
ALEX. COOKE.
With the allowance of the Master of REVELLS.
